# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Sure, Here is the solution using Julia:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # filter to get rows with manufacturer as 'audi' and model as 'a4 or a4 quattro'
    df_new = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    
    # add new column 'audi_a4_type' as true across all rows
    df_new[:audi_a4_type] = fill(true, size(df_new)[1])
    
    return df_new
end
```
To use this function and view the output:

```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])

df_new = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
After running `audi_filter` function, you can see that a new column `audi_a4_type` is added with all values as true. The DataFrame `df_new` will have the same rows as in your input DataFrame `df_cars`, but with the additional column `audi_a4_type`. 

This solution uses the DataFrames package which is part of Julia's standard library.
